# Dates and Times {#sec-dates-times} Working with dates and times can be a little tricky, but the lubridate", "https://lubridate.tidyverse.org/")` package is there to help. Their website has a helpful [cheatsheet](https://rawgit.com/rstudio/cheatsheets/main/lubridate.pdf) and you can view a tutorial by typing `vignette("lubridate")` in the console pane. The [Dates and Times](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/dates-and-times.html){target="_blank"} in R for Data Science also gives a helpful overview. This appendix is a quick intro to some of the most useful functions for making reproducible reports. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # packages needed for this appendix library(tidyverse) library(lubridate) ``` ::: ## Parsing Dates can be in many formats. The `ymd` functions can deal with almost all of them, regardless of the punctuation used in the format. All of the examples below produce a date in the standard format "2022-01-03". ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # year-month-day orders ymd("22 Jan 3") ymd("2022 January 3rd") # month-day-year orders mdy("January 3, 2022") mdy("Jan/03/22") # day-month-year orders dmy("3JAN22") dmy("3rd of January in the year 2022") ``` ::: ::: {.callout-note .try} See if you can make a date format that one of the parsers *can't* handle. ::: There are similar functions for date/times, too. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ymd_hms("2022 Jan 3, 6:05 and 20s pm") mdy_h("January 3rd, 2022 at 6pm") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2022-01-03 18:05:20 UTC" [1] "2022-01-03 18:00:00 UTC" ``` ::: ::: The date/time functions can also take a timezone argument. If you don't specify it, it defaults to "UTC". ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ymd_hm("2022-01-03 18:05", tz = "GMT") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2022-01-03 18:05:00 GMT" ``` ::: ::: ## Get Parts You frequently need to extract parts of a date/time for plotting. The following functions extract specific parts of a date or datetime object. This is a godsend for those of us who never have a clue what week of the year it is today. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # get the date and time when this function is run now <- now(tzone = "GMT") # get separate parts time_parts <- list( second = second(now), minute = minute(now), hour = hour(now), day = day(now), # day of the month (same as mday()) wday = wday(now), # day of the week yday = yday(now), # day of the year week = week(now), isoweek = isoweek(now), # ISO 8501 week calendar (Monday start) epiweek = epiweek(now), # CDC epidemiological week (Sunday Start) month = month(now), year = year(now), tz = tz(now) ) str(time_parts) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` List of 12 $ second : num 49.2 $ minute : int 49 $ hour : int 14 $ day : int 21 $ wday : num 4 $ yday : num 355 $ week : num 51 $ isoweek: num 51 $ epiweek: num 51 $ month : num 12 $ year : num 2022 $ tz : chr "GMT" ``` ::: ::: The `month()` and `wday()` functions can return factor labels. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} jan1 <- ymd(20220101) wday(jan1, label = TRUE) wday(jan1, label = TRUE, abbr = TRUE) month(jan1, label = TRUE) month(jan1, label = TRUE, abbr = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Sat Levels: Sun < Mon < Tue < Wed < Thu < Fri < Sat [1] Sat Levels: Sun < Mon < Tue < Wed < Thu < Fri < Sat [1] Jan 12 Levels: Jan < Feb < Mar < Apr < May < Jun < Jul < Aug < Sep < ... < Dec [1] Jan 12 Levels: Jan < Feb < Mar < Apr < May < Jun < Jul < Aug < Sep < ... < Dec ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note .try} What day of the week were you born? ::: {.cell layout-align="center" webex.hide='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} birthdate <- ymd(19761118) # put your own birthdate here wday(birthdate, label = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Thu Levels: Sun < Mon < Tue < Wed < Thu < Fri < Sat ``` :::
::: ::: ## Date Arithmetic You can add and subtract dates. For example, you can get the dates two weeks from today by adding `weeks(2)` to `today()`. You can probably guess how to add and subtract seconds, minutes, days, months, and years. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} today() + weeks(1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2022-12-28" ``` ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note .try} What day of the week will your 100th birthday be? ::: {.cell layout-align="center" webex.hide='true'}
```{.r .cell-code} birthdate <- ymd(19761118) # put your own birthdate here centennial <- birthdate + years(100) wday(centennial, label = TRUE, abbr = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] Wednesday 7 Levels: Sunday < Monday < Tuesday < Wednesday < Thursday < ... < Saturday ``` :::
::: ::: ::: {.callout-warning} What do you think will happen if you subtract one month from March 31st? You get NA, since February doesn't have a 31st day. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ymd(20220331) - months(1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] NA ``` ::: ::: Use the special date operators `%m+%` and `%m-%` to add and subtract months without risking an impossible date. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ymd(20220331) %m-% months(1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2022-02-28" ``` ::: ::: ::: ### First and last of month For things like billing, you might need to find the first or last days of the current, previous, or next month. The `rollback()` and `rollforward()` functions are easier than trying to parse dates. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} d <- ymd("2022-01-24") rollback(d) # last day of the previous month rollforward(d) # last day of the current month rollback(d, roll_to_first = TRUE) # first day of the current month rollforward(d, roll_to_first = TRUE) # first day of the next month ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2021-12-31" [1] "2022-01-31" [1] "2022-01-01" [1] "2022-02-01" ``` ::: ::: ### Rounding You can round dates and times to the nearest unit. This can be useful when you have, for example, time measured to the nearest second, but want to group data by the nearest hour, rather than extract the hour component. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ymd_hm("2022-01-24 10:25") %>% round_date(unit = "hour") ymd_hm("2022-01-24 10:30") %>% round_date(unit = "hour") ymd_hm("2022-01-24 10:35") %>% round_date(unit = "hour") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2022-01-24 10:00:00 UTC" [1] "2022-01-24 11:00:00 UTC" [1] "2022-01-24 11:00:00 UTC" ``` ::: ::: ## Internationalisation You may need to work with dates from a different locale than your computer's defaults, such as dates written in French or Russian. Or your computer may have a non-English locale. Set the `locale` argument to the relevant language code. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} ymd("2022 January 24", locale = "en_GB") ymd("2022 Janvier 24", locale = "fr_FR") wday("2022-01-03", label = TRUE, locale = "ru_RU") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "2022-01-24" [1] "2022-01-24" [1] пн Levels: вс < пн < вт < ср < чт < пт < сб ``` ::: ::: Some of the locale functions only work on unix-based machines, like Macs or machines running linux. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # check your own locale; doesn't work for Windows locale() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Numbers: 123,456.78 Formats: %AD / %AT Timezone: UTC Encoding: UTF-8 Days: Sunday (Sun), Monday (Mon), Tuesday (Tue), Wednesday (Wed), Thursday (Thu), Friday (Fri), Saturday (Sat) Months: January (Jan), February (Feb), March (Mar), April (Apr), May (May), June (Jun), July (Jul), August (Aug), September (Sep), October (Oct), November (Nov), December (Dec) AM/PM: AM/PM ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # check which locales are available on your computer # doesn't work for Windows system("locale -a") ``` ::: ## Example Let's work through some examples with downloaded tweets from the [class data](data/data.zip). ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} # read all metrics files in data/tweets/ tweets <- list.files( path = "data/tweets", pattern = "^tweet_activity_metrics", full.names = TRUE ) %>% map_df(read_csv) %>% select(!starts_with("promoted")) ``` ::: The `time` column is already in date/time (POSIXct) format, but what if we wanted to plot tweets by hour for each day of the week? ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tweets %>% mutate(weekday = wday(time, label = TRUE), hour = hour(time)) %>% ggplot(aes(x = hour, fill = weekday)) + geom_bar(size = 1, alpha = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE) + facet_grid(~weekday) + scale_fill_manual(values = rainbow(7)) + scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 24, 4)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](app-dates_files/figure-html/weekday-tweets-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: A nice side-effect of using the lubridate function to get days of the week or months of the year is that the results are an ordered factor, so display correctly in a plot. Let's display the months in Greek (if that's available on your system). ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tweets %>% mutate(month = month(time, label = TRUE, abbr = FALSE, locale = "el_GR.UTF-8")) %>% ggplot(aes(x = month, fill = month)) + geom_bar(show.legend = FALSE) + scale_x_discrete(name = NULL, guide = guide_axis(n.dodge=2)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](app-dates_files/figure-html/month-tweets-1.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: :::
